title: Benchmarking does not run when the results are stored on google cloud
body:
A couple of gsutil commands crash when working with google cloud:

- When launching a benchmark cluster, the method `remove_benchmark_logs` attempts to remove a non-existing folder and crashes. Considering that, AFAIK, there is already a step that checks if a benchmark with the same name already exists and demands it to be removed, maybe this method is not useful anymore.

- When showing a benchmark for the second time, `benchmark_utils.update_benchmark_state(benchmark)` attempts to use the gsutil cp command, but it crashes because the target location already exists

title: How long does benchmarking takes ?
body:
I am currently running a benchmark on a task.
It has been running for close to an hour.

How long does the benchmark take ? Considering many tasks are launched in parallel, the costs add up very quickly. 
Therefore it should be possible to provide a maximum duration or number of steps before stopping the benchmark.

I haven't seen anything related to that in the documentation.

title: [k8s] handle network error from pulling docker image
body:
<!-- Describe the changes in this PR -->
This resolves #2523 

Some users have network restrictions and this prevents them from pulling the docker image from registry while creating the node(pod). And when this prevention happens, our sky launch was silently stalling without failing early. This PR resolves this issue by failing early and releasing the scheduled pod. 

To reproduce the image pull failure event with networking error, it was necessary to block the registry domain, us-central1-docker.pkg.dev. This can be done by adding 
```
127.0.0.1    us-central1-docker.pkg.dev
```

to `/etc/hosts`. 

To reproduce this with `kind` setting, we would have to set 
```
127.0.0.1    us-central1-docker.pkg.dev
```
at `/etc/hosts` in the node container rather than directly in the machine where you are running `kind`. The node container appears to have the name of `skypilot-control-plane` when running `docker ps`, and the interactive session can be entered by running `docker exec -it skypilot-control-plane /bin/bash`. We need to handle this differently as `kind` simulates a node with docker container, which is in our case, `skypilot-control-plane`. And kubelet for `kind` shares its networking setting with the node container rather than the machine running `kind`.



<!-- Describe the tests ran -->
<!-- Unit tests (tests/test_*.py) are part of GitHub CI; below are tests that launch on the cloud. -->

Tested (run the relevant ones):

- [x] Code formatting: `bash format.sh`
- [x] Manual testing for kind/GKE by blocking registry domain ensuring early fail over

title: [Core] SkyPilot environment variables are not available in `setup`
body:
My LLM training script requires some setup that must happen only on the head node. However,  `SKYPILOT_NODE_RANK` is not available in the `setup` phase, causing the same `setup` to be run on all nodes.

Since `SKYPILOT_NODE_RANK` is only set during `run`, it forces me to put one-time setup commands in the run section. Additionally, I need to handle idempotency (i.e., add special code to not run the same code twice) for this code in the `run` section

title: [Spot] Support both managed on-demand and spot instances
body:
<!-- Describe the changes in this PR -->

From discussion with @Michaelvll 
- Allow serverless style job submission for on-demand jobs.
   - Conceptually, the API contains two kinds of jobs, serverful (launch, exec, start, stop), and serverless (spot launch). 
   - However, the serverless API is only spot oriented. It could be better to have on-demand support as well, and rename the spot launch to something like serverless launch.
   - This will benefit the TPU users, as the on-demand TPUs can still have quite frequent restart due to stability issue. 
   - Small cloud users may benefit from this as well, for improved reliability
- Design a way to select from both on-demand and spot instances.
   - Smaller cloud have quite cheap on-demand with similar price points as spot
   - Good for optimizer to choose among both on-demand instances and spot.

Possibly replace `use_spot: True` with
```
managed: SPOT
# managed: ON_DEMAND
# managed: CONSIDER_BOTH
```

title: [k8s] `sky start/launch` fails if kubeconfig is missing and k8s is enabled
body:
`sky start/launch` fails on regular clouds if kubeconfig file is missing and Kubernetes cloud is enabled (i.e., user has not run `sky check` again after removing their kubeconfig file and SkyPilot still thinks k8s is enabled). Currently can be fixed by running `sky check`.

We may need to add some lightweight pre-flight checks if k8s is enabled before invoking the optimizer and/or improve logging to suggest running `sky check`. 

Logs for [sky stop](https://gist.github.com/romilbhardwaj/d229f36b3d5dc0f67a6a103125393d68) and [sky start](https://gist.github.com/romilbhardwaj/1f862e4e4b5a31919f7b3c1b8bcdd0ef).

Reproduction for `sky start` issue:

1. `sky launch -c myclus--cloud gcp`
2. `sky stop myclus`
3. `sky local up`
4. `rm ~/.kube/config`
5. `sky start myclus`

Reproduction for `sky launch` issue:
1. `sky local up`
2. `rm ~/.kube/config`
3. `sky launch -c test`

title: [Core] Fix type of `job_id` when querying job status
body:
<!-- Describe the changes in this PR -->

Previously, our `common_utils.encode_payload` used `json.dumps` to handle a dictionary with integer and `None` type as key, which will not be restored as the original type in default `json.loads` implementation; also, our click treat `job_id` as string, causing a lot of problems. This PR fixes these problems.

```bash
$ sky logs --status g 1
Getting job status...
{'1': None, 1: 'SUCCEEDED'}
<sky-payload>{"1": null, "1": "SUCCEEDED"}</sky-payload>

{'1': <JobStatus.SUCCEEDED: 'SUCCEEDED'>}
Job 1: SUCCEEDED
```

title: [GCP] Enable time sync for GCP clusters
body:
After having a GCP cluster UP for months, the system time has been shifted by 6 mins, which causes the awscli calls fail. We should enable automatic time sync for the system, such as:
```
sudo systemctl start ntp
sudo systemctl enable ntp
```

body:
PRs created by external contributors fail on `poetry-build-test` since it tries checking out branch from main skypilot repo, not the PR's source repo. [Example run](https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/actions/runs/6131701431/job/16641911660?pr=2242).

```
Failed to clone https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot.git at 'derek-falcon-example', verify ref exists on remote.
Error: Process completed with exit code 1.
```

This line probably needs to be updated to use the PR's source repo:
https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/blob/e164dc29fc9aee2b14c4abe634af9b3b84e9a806/.github/workflows/test-poetry-build.yml#L39

title: [Enhancement][Sky Serve] Support a mix of spot and on-demand instances
body:
Hey there,  I recently saw #2528 and thought of an enhancement that I would personally find very valuable, so I figured I'd share it here.

The feature in that PR is to allow spot instances to serve inference requests. This is indeed a very useful feature for managing costs, but it's not something I could depend on in production, because the availability of spot instances can dry up suddenly if large compute jobs are launched.

What would be amazing, is to have a feature that says "if the number of instances is below a threshold, then spin up regular instances to maintain high availability". Once demand subsides, then these would be replaced with spot nodes.

In short: availability is the highest priority, followed by saving cost as a secondary concern.

title: Cluster gets stuck in INIT state when pulling docker image fails
body:
I'm running into an issue when launching a local Kubernetes cluster for the skypilot project where the cluster gets stuck in an INIT state if the docker image pull fails. (skypilot commit: 7d59ff9b4c2306c85ef61aa8026a0f2a24b8608c)

Specifically, when the image us-central1-docker.pkg.dev/skypilot-375900/skypilotk8s/skypilot:latest is unable to be pulled due to network restrictions. This leaves the cluster in an initializing state.

Attempts to stop or terminate the cluster fail with the error:
```
Terminating cluster sky-0e1c...failed.
Reason: builtins.RuntimeError: Cluster 'sky-0e1c-xxx' is locked by /home/xxxx/.sky/.sky-0e1c-xxx.lock. Check to see if it is still being launched..
```
It seems the INIT state can only be resolved by waiting for the cluster launch to time out.

Is there a way to gracefully handle or recover from a failed docker image pull during cluster initialization? Being stuck in this state blocks re-use of the cluster name as well.

Let me know if any other details would be helpful!

title: Cuda not working via skypilot (works on direct instance)
body:
Here's some minimal code to repro:

cuda.py
``` python
import torch

print(f"torch.cuda.is_available(): {torch.cuda.is_available()}")
print(f"torch.cuda.device_count(): {torch.cuda.device_count()}")
print(f"torch.cuda.current_device(): {torch.cuda.current_device()}")
print(f"torch.cuda.device(0): {torch.cuda.device(0)}")
print(f"torch.cuda.get_device_name(0): {torch.cuda.get_device_name(0)}")
```

hello_sky.yaml:
``` yaml
# Working directory (optional) containing the project codebase.
# Its contents are synced to ~/sky_workdir/ on the cluster.
workdir: .

# Typical use: pip install -r requirements.txt
# Invoked under the workdir (i.e., can use its files).
setup: |
  echo "Running setup."
  pip3 install torch

# Typical use: make use of resources, such as running training.
# Invoked under the workdir (i.e., can use its files).
run: |
  echo "Hello, SkyPilot!"
  conda env list
  python cuda.py
```

Running `sky launch -c mycluster hello_sky.yaml` results in this output:

``` bash
(task, pid=201122) Hello, SkyPilot!

(task, pid=201122) #

(task, pid=201122)   File "/home/ubuntu/miniconda3/lib/python3.10/site-packages/torch/cuda/__init__.py", line 247, in _lazy_init
(task, pid=201122)     torch._C._cuda_init()
(task, pid=201122) RuntimeError: No CUDA GPUs are available

ERROR: Job 4 failed with return code list: [1]
INFO: Job finished (status: FAILED).
Shared connection to 129.153.155.195 closed.
I 09-04 14:34:32 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:3258] Job ID: 4
I 09-04 14:34:32 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:3258] To cancel the job:       sky cancel mycluster 4
```

As you can see, the cluster clearly has an A10 GPU.
Just to be sure, I opened the instance in Lambda directly, and opened a notebook to run the same code, which successfully detects the GPU.

``` python
import torch

print(f"torch.cuda.is_available(): {torch.cuda.is_available()}")
```

Am I missing some configuration settings in my yaml to ensure skypilot has access to the GPUs?

title: [Storage] Precheck the existence of file mounts.
body:
The following command will go ahead to launch the cluster, but fail after the cluster is launched. We should check the existence of the source in filemounts, before launching the cluster:

```
# test.yaml
file_mounts:
  /data:
    source: gs://existing-bucket/non-existing-folder
    mode: COPY
```

title: [Spot] Failed to catch user file mounts error which causes the retry forever
body:
Observed by @infwinston and a user, that if a file mounts error happens, the spot job will not become `FAILED`, but instead retry forever.

To reproduce:
1. `sky spot launch -n test-fm test.yaml`
2. terminate the spot cluster

```
# test.yaml

file_mounts:
  /data:
    source: gs://existing-bucket/non-exist-folder
    mode: copy
```

The spot job will keep retrying forever, as we did not catch the storage error.
To fix the issue, we can catch the storage exceptions in the following place and raise `ProvisionPrechecksError` to avoid retrying:
https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/blob/3213d3a14ecd86c3022f071e671fcf62c5ca48ba/sky/spot/recovery_strategy.py#L331-L336

title: [K8s] Zero config networking for Kubernetes
body:
This PR introduces new networking features for our Kubernetes support. In particular, we no longer need opening many ports on the Kubernetes cluster nodes. Now we support two modes of operation:

1. `portforward`: Open no ports, and we use `kubectl port-forward` under the hood to reach the pods. This requires zero configuration on the user's end, and is only marginally worse (~10%) in performance (see benchmarks). Given the significantly better UX, this will the default mode of operation. 
2. `nodeport`: Open 1 port, and we run a ssh jump pod on that port to reach other pods. This requires opening one port on any one node in the Kubernetes cluster, and offers the highest performance while minimizing the number of open ports needed.

Users who don't want to use `portforward` can switch to `nodeport` by modifying their `~/.sky/config` file:
```
kubernetes:
  networking: nodeport
```

Note that we currently create one jump pod per user. Eventually, we want to share the jump pod across many users (See #2499)

--------
This PR also has other bug fixes, including populating k8s envvars when the user runs SSH (#2287 and #2453 will also be closed by this PR).

Thanks to @landscapepainter, @aviweit and @hemildesai for their contributions.

Tested (run the relevant ones):

- [x] Code formatting: `bash format.sh`
- [x] `pytest tests/test_smoke.py --kubernetes -k "not TestStorageWithCredentials"`
- [x] Ensure #2453 is fixed

title: [k8s] Share SSH jump pod across users
body:
For nodeport networking mode, we currently create one jump pod per user. Ideally want to share the same jump pod across users to minimize the number of open ports required and/or resource consumption. 

Potential solutions include assuming a common namespace is accessible to all users, and creating/running the jumppod in this shared namespace. Need to validate this design choice with users first.

title: [Core] Support Multiple Resources
body:
<!-- Describe the changes in this PR -->

This partially builds upon an old PR #1389. 
The user can specify an ordered _preference list_ or an unordered _restriction set_ for accelerators.
_Ordered preference list_. The user prefers `A100-40GB:1` over `V100:1`, etc. The optimizer will follow user-specified order in picking the accelerators.
```
accelerators: ['A100-40GB:1', 'V100:1', 'K80:1', 'T4:1']
```
_Unordered restriction set_. The user specifies multiple accelerators for accelerator to choose from, with no preference among them.
```
accelerators: {'A100-40GB:1', 'K80:1', 'V100:1', 'T4:1', 'T4:4'}
```

title: [Storage][k8s] Support mounting data sources on Kubernetes cluster
body:
K8s users often have data locally stored on the cluster, typically in the form of a persistent volume + pvc, or a NFS mounted to all nodes, accessed via a hostpath. 

From a user:
```
We have to use the hostpath instead because we cannot transfer the whole datasets directory to the pvc. I want the option to add the pvc or hostpath to the task.yaml.
```

Our k8s features needs to add support for attaching and accessing data on persistent volumes, hostpaths and/or any other mechanism used by users to access their local data.

title: [k8s] Possible fix for: Could not resolve hostname: Temporary failure in name resolution.
body:
When multiple ray clusters exist in a same kubernetes cluster and one of them is being removed by `sky down` then a wrong entry might be deleted from `~/.ssh/config` that could then lead to an ssh error when attempting to ssh into ray head of a remaining cluster.

Current kubernetes support (in master branch) uses NodePort to access ray clusters where the IP is the same for all ray nodes.

The PR updates `found` criteria at `remove_cluster` to search for `Host <cluster name>`.

title: [UX] Make logger safe with rich status
body:
<!-- Describe the changes in this PR -->

Previously, the `logger.info/warning/etc` will conflict with the rich status, causing the logging message appearing in the same line as the spinner. This PR fixes it by stopping and restarting the spinner when the message is being printed.


This PR is introduced for #2481, but should be generally useful for other places where `logger` and `rich.Status` is being used together.

title: [Provisioner] Update ports for UP cluster
body:
<!-- Describe the changes in this PR -->

This PR introduces the ability to update ports. When you execute `sky launch -c existing-cluster port.yaml`, it will automatically detect ports that have not been opened and open them. All opened ports will be closed when the cluster is tear down.

`sky exec` will continue to check port requirements and will not execute any task if the required ports haven't been opened in the cluster.

Also, this PR:
* Accept single ports argument;
* Add CLI option for ports;
* Change the internal type of ports to `List[str]`.

title: [GCP] ssh profile exceeds 32 KB
body:
A user using os-login on GCP experienced the following issue:
```
(test, pid=4305) I 08-27 23:04:50 authentication.py:192] OS Login is enabled for GCP project <project-id>. Running additional authentication steps.
(test, pid=4305) ERROR: (gcloud.compute.os-login.ssh-keys.add) INVALID_ARGUMENT: Login profile size exceeds 32 KiB. Delete profile values to make additional space.
(test, pid=4305) W 08-27 23:04:52 common_utils.py:350] Caught Command 'gcloud compute os-login ssh-keys add --key-file=/<user>/.ssh/sky-key.pub' returned non-zero exit status 1.. Retrying.
```

It is because multiple spot controllers have been started and deleted, i.e., multiple ssh key pairs are uploaded to the project, causing too many ssh key in the project. The problem is solved by manually deleting some of the keys with `gcloud compute os-login ssh-key remove --key='<key>'`.

We should automatically deal with this: either make the os-login to use the same logic for setting up ssh key (instead of `gcloud compute os-login ssh-key add` as we did in the following (https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/blob/469a62d9ac20043f6d267edcf04f5928dae65034/sky/authentication.py#L244-L249), or we should do some LRU.

title: [config] Pre-checks for `~/.sky/config.yaml`
body:
Currently, we don't have a way to pre-check the `~/.sky/config.yaml`, making it very easy to miss spell or setting wrong configs in the yaml. We can apply the json schema check to the `~/.sky/config.yaml` to make sure there is no unexpected settings.

A user met the issue when specifying the spot controller's resources requirement, but missing one section (`resources`):
```
spot:
  controller:
    cloud: gcp
    region: us-west1
```

title: [SkyServe] Fix bugs
body:
